children.text:
Starting with the 'power' function. Let's write a function in Fortran:

FUNCTION power(a) RESULT(res)
  INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: a
  INTEGER :: res
  res = 0
  DO WHILE (a > 0)
    res = res +1
    a = a / 10
  END DO
END FUNCTION power

Wait, but in Fortran, integers can't be modified in a function if they are passed as INTENT(IN). Wait, right! So in the function, the variable 'a' is an input-only. So perhaps to avoid modifying the original variable, we need to create a working variable inside. Let's see. Wait the original code in Java: inside power, a is modified.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Since in Java function parameters are pass-by-value, so the original variable isn't modified.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: So, in the Java function, the initial a is copied into the local parameter.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Hence, in Fortran function, since if we have to modify a, even though it's a parameter, we need to make a local copy. Therefore, the function would better be written as:

FUNCTION power(a) RESULT(res)
  INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: a
  INTEGER :: res, num
  num = a
  res = 0
  DO WHILE (num > 0) res = res + 1
    num = num / 10
  END DO
END FUNCTION power

That should avoid modifying the original a because we make a copy in 'num'.

program codeforces_86_A
  implicit none

  integer, parameter :: INT64 = selected_int_kind(18)
  
  interface
    integer function power(a)
      integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
    end function power
    integer(INT64) function mult(a)
       integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
    end function mult
  end interface

  integer(INT64) :: l, r, res, temp, i, pow
  integer(INT64), dimension(0:9) :: maxxes
  character :: newline = achar(10)

  l = 0
  r =0
  read(*,*) l, r
  res = 0_INT64

  temp =0_INT64
  do i = 0,9
     temp = temp *10_INT64 + 9_INT64
     maxxes(i) = (temp/2) * (temp - temp/2)
  end do

  res = max( res, mult(l) )
  res = max( res, mult(r) )

  temp = 0_INT64
  do i =0,9
     temp = temp*10_INT64 +9_INT64
     if ( (l <= temp/2 ) .and. ( temp/2 <= r ) ) then
        res = max( res, maxxes(i) )
     end if
  end do

  write(*,*) res

integer function power(a)
  integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
  integer :: res
  integer(INT64) :: num
  num = a

  end do

end function

integer(INT64) function mult(a)
  integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
  integer :: pow
  integer(INT64) :: max_val

  max_val =0_INT64
  do i=1, pow

  end do
  mult = a * (max_val -a

including the functions.

Wait, in Fortran, functions are either internal, or external, but since versions before F90 had different conventions, but let's use F90 standard.

Structure:

First, program defines the functions, then the main.

But in Fortran, subroutines and functions must be declared before the program if in the same file. Alternatively, putting them before the main program in the code.

So:

program codeforces_86_A
  implicit none

  integer, parameter :: INT64 = selected_int_kind(18)
  
  interface
    integer function power(a)
      integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
    end function power
    integer(INT64) function mult(a)
       integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
    end function mult
  end interface

  integer(INT64) :: l, r, res, temp, i, pow
  integer(INT64), dimension(0:9) :: maxxes
  character :: newline = achar(10)

  l = 0
  r =0
  read(*,*) l, r
  res = 0_INT64

  temp =0_INT64
  do i = 0,9
     temp = temp *10_INT64 + 9_INT64
     maxxes(i) = (temp/2) * (temp - temp/2)
  end do

  res = max( res, mult(l) )
  res = max( res, mult(r) )

  temp = 0_INT64
  do i =0,9
     temp = temp*10_INT64 +9_INT64
     if ( (l <= temp/2 ) .and. ( temp/2 <= r ) ) then
        res = max( res, maxxes(i) )
     end if
  end do

  write(*,*) res

contains

integer function power(a)
  integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
  integer :: res
  integer(INT64) :: num
  num = a
  res =0
  do while ( num >0 )
     res = res +1
     num = num /10
  end do
  power = res
end function

integer(INT64) function mult(a)
  integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
  integer :: pow
  integer(INT64) :: max_val
  pow = power(a)
  max_val =0_INT64
  do i=1, pow
     max_val = max_val *10_INT64 +9_INT64
  end do
  mult = a * (max_val -a)
end function mult

end program codeforces_86_A

Because in the main program, the 'i' variable is used in loops, but in the mult function, using 'i' would refer to the main program's i, which is incorrect. To avoid variable collision, in Fortran, the loop variables in the function need to be declared or use a different name.

integer(INT64) function mult(a)
  integer(INT64), intent(in) :: a
  integer :: pow, j
  integer(INT64) :: max_val
  pow = power(a)
  max_val =0_INT64
  do j =1, pow  ! changing the loop variable to j
     max_val = max_val *10_INT64 +9_INT64
  end do
  mult = a * (max_val -a)
end function mult
